info.game_comments:
2008 College Championship final game 1.
From the Kohl Center at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

(1, 1).clue: Born in Ladysmith, Wisc., Ron Kovic wrote "Born on the Fourth of July" about his experiences in this war

(2, 1).clue: For Julie Andrews, the hills were alive with this, the title of a 1965 musical

(3, 1).clue: Yum!  The Chocolate Shoppe Ice Cream Co. here in Madison has a black ice cream named for this black candy

(4, 1).clue: In 1998 her "Pandora" came out of the box as the first of her "New Tales of the Vampires"

(5, 1).clue: "Ura!" for Dmitry Medvedev, voted in as president of Russia as this man moves over to become prime minister

(1, 2).clue: Arthur Miller's "The Crucible" was a veiled critique of the 1950s witch hunt bearing the name of this Wisconsin senator

(2, 2).clue: Jimmy Stewart finds out what it would be like if he'd never been born in this Christmas film

(3, 2).clue: Sheboygan is the "Capital of the World" for these, "brats" for short--let's go there right now

(4, 2).clue: Corruption runs rampant in Gore Vidal's historical novel named for this centennial year

(5, 2).clue: Helen Clark enacted interest-free student loans for colleges like the U. of Auckland in this country

(6, 2).clue: The Jewish Exodus from Egypt is thought to have occurred during his rule

(1, 3).clue: Born in Pepin, she headed out on "the prairie" as a young girl & wrote about it in a series of bestselling books

(2, 3).clue: Organized crime is the real Corleone family business in this 1972 classic

(3, 3).clue: I could really use a deep-fried one of these candy bars whose name also means "disrespectful laughs"

(4, 3).clue: "In the world according to Garp, we're all terminal cases", wrote this novelist

(5, 3).clue: Kudos to Kofi Annan, who brokered Pres. Kibaki & Raila Odinga's power-sharing deal in this country

(6, 3).clue: Its altar wall once displayed Perugino's "Nativity"

(1, 4).clue: Deke Slayton of Sparta, Wisconsin was one of the original 7 astronauts in this "planetary" group

(2, 4).clue: Margaret Hamilton played Miss Gulch & the Wicked Witch in this film

(3, 4).clue: Moo!  I'll have the Baraboo Candy Company's chocolate treat known as this kind of "pie"

(4, 4).clue: Kim Edwards called her memorable first novel "The Memory Keeper's" this

(5, 4).clue: Conservative PM Stephen Harper is working to lower the wait times in the national health care system of this country

(6, 4).clue: A thrown object; as a verb, it can mean to cause harm to the originator

(1, 5).clue: In 1925 Chippewa Falls produced this mathematician hailed as the father of the supercomputer

(2, 5).clue: This 1975 comedy includes the line "We are the knights who say Ni!"
(2, 5).correct response: Monty Python and the Holy Grail

(3, 5).clue: I'd love some coeur a la creme, a cheesy dessert molded in this shape

(4, 5).clue: "The story of Nat Turner had been long gestating in my mind, ever since I was a boy", said this novelist

(5, 5).clue: Felipe Calderon received the NAFTA Congressional Leadership Award before becoming president of this country

(6, 5).clue: Dog-faced monkey of the genus Papio

(1, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from the Lima Cathedral in Peru.) In 1687 & 1746, Lima's cathedral along with much of the city was nearly destroyed by one of these; 2007 brought grim news of another one nearby

(2, 1).clue: Playing on their native soil, this country's Hockeyroos won gold in 2000

(3, 1).clue: A porky isn't a pig but this rodent that you don't want to approach too closely

(4, 1).clue: Scouts precede the main flock of these birds in their annual arrival at San Juan Capistrano

(5, 1).clue: Oops!  The daughter of this nasty mean czar is killed by accident in "The Maid of Pskov"

(6, 1).clue: To lie close & snug; I just wanna do this

(1, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from Lima, Peru.)  Lima is known as the city of balconies, which are in the style inspired by these Spanish Muslims

(2, 2).clue: In August 2004, the shot put competition was held not in this main host city but at Olympia

(3, 2).clue: If this U.S. marsupial keeps getting into my garbage, it won't just be playing dead

(4, 2).clue: After he returned home to Venice in 1295, he was called "Il Milione", the "man with a million stories"

(5, 2).clue: An evil opium dealer is strangled with his own pigtail in "L'Oracolo", set in this California city's Chinatown

(6, 2).clue: Yogi Berra allegedly said of a busy restaurant, "Nobody goes there anymore, it's too" this

(1, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from a market in Peru.) Textile crafts of Peru include sweaters made of wool from these beasts, the most important llama relatives for wool production

(2, 3).clue: This onetime ally of the host nation won the most medals at the 2006 Turin games

(3, 3).clue: This varmint is wrecking my fence posts, but oh, the little wussy is protected by the Migratory Bird Treaty Act

(4, 3).clue: The painting seen here shows Odysseus returning home to find this wife of his delaying some suitors

(5, 3).clue: In "Maria Stuarda", this woman signs the death warrant of her cousin Mary Queen of Scots

(1, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from a square in Lima, Peru.)  It was here in Lima in 1821 that this Argentine general declared Peru's independence from Spain

(2, 4).clue: It was the most recent year when the Olympics were held in the U.S.

(3, 4).clue: These nocturnal ringtailed mammals find that a chimney makes an excellent den

(4, 4).clue: A Supreme Court ruling from 1841 said Africans from this ship should be free & not become Cuban slaves

(5, 4).clue: The murdered King Nino returns as a ghost in "Semiramide" by this "William Tell" composer

(6, 4).clue: Scent hounds include beagles, harriers & these "sausage dogs"

(1, 5).clue: (Alex reports from Machu Picchu.) In order to deal with the problems of erosion & farming on steep hillsides, the Incas came up with this brilliant solution--& they used it a lot

(2, 5).clue: The Los Angeles Olympics of this year had the games' first paraplegic athlete, archer Neroli Fairhall

(3, 5).clue: It's also called a brush wolf, & I can't forgive the one that took our cat Fluffy when she got out one night

(4, 5).clue: This Tammany Hall ringleader was jailed in 1873 but escaped to Spain in 1876; Spain returned him later that year

(5, 5).clue: Schlemil is killed in a duel in "The Tales of" this German author

(6, 5).clue: "You did well, for a Nebraskan" is this type of compliment

(0, 0).clue: On January 18, 1912 he arrived at a tent near the pole & found "a record of five Norwegians having been there"
